Description: Two fragments from neck and shoulder of (one?) black-figured pottery closed vase. Inside reserved. On neck, A) a swan being held around the neck by a figure of which only an arm and leg are visible and surrounded by filling motifs; uncertain object to right, probably raised paw of a lion. B) A griffin surrounded by filling motifs on neck; part of lip, glazed, and on shoulder part of an animal and rosettes preserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 223, nos 99-100)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 107, pl. XXXIV, no. 319.1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.160)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5955a-b (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
